article.name: Defend - KnowBe4 Simulation Emails
article.title: Defend - KnowBe4 Simulation Emails
article.body:
If you have followed KnowBe4's advice and set up the Advanced Delivery Policy (ADP) as documented in this article (https://support.knowbe4.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404511190803-Advanced-Delivery-Policies-in-Microsoft-Defender-for-Office-365), then you’ll likely see in Microsoft 365 message tracking that the simulation emails arrive in Microsoft 365 and successfully go across to the Defend console. However, when emails come back, they are quarantined.

The reason for this process is that the ADP lists specific IP addresses and domains from which the simulation emails are sent, and the Defend IP address is not listed there.

Resolution

If you experience this issue, add the Defend outbound IP addresses to the existing ADP in your Microsoft 365 tenancy.

All of our sending IP addresses for your respective region can be found below:

    • 18.130.212.176
    • 18.135.85.199
    • 13.43.19.144/29
    • 3.253.208.184/29
    • 52.71.53.79
    • 34.204.210.91
    • 52.0.5.153

Ensure that psm.knowbe4.com is added to the domains in the Advanced Delivery Policy:

Ensure that the following options are not enabled in KnowBe4's console under Account Settings Phishing Settings:

This image displays a configuration screen titled "**Advanced delivery**," part of a security or mail management application.

**UI Elements and Navigation:**

*   **Title:** "Advanced delivery" is the primary heading.
*   **Tabs:** Two navigation tabs are visible: "SecOps mailbox" and "**Phishing simulation**." The "Phishing simulation" tab is active, indicated by the blue underline.
*   **Actions:** Below the tabs are action links: "Edit" (with a pencil icon) and "Refresh" (with a circular arrow icon).
*   **Item Count and View Controls:** In the top right, the count "**8 items**" is displayed, followed by view control icons (a stacked line/menu icon and a dropdown arrow).

**Data Table:**

The primary content is a table listing exceptions related to phishing simulations, featuring three columns:

1.  **Value:** Lists IP addresses (IPv4 and CIDR notation) and one domain name.
2.  **Type:** Specifies the classification of the Value.
3.  **Date:** Shows the timestamp of entry.

images.alt:
This image depicts a system configuration page within a web application, focused on email phishing settings.

**UI Layout and Navigation (Left Pane):**
The left pane serves as a navigation menu. The currently selected and expanded section is **Phishing** (indicated by blue text and a downward chevron). Sub-links visible under Phishing include **Phishing Settings** and **Direct Message Injection (DMI)**. Collapsed sections (indicated by right chevrons) are **Training** and **Account Integrations**. A footer link, **Expand All**, is also present.

**Configuration Content (Right Pane):**
The right pane presents the detailed configuration options. At the top, there is an informational link, **View Our Localization Guide**, accompanied by an icon.

Settings are divided into sections using headings and controls:

1.  **Reply-to Phishing** (Section Header):
    *   Checkbox Control: Overwrite Sender Address with Reply-to Address for OOO Replies (Unchecked, with help icon).
    *   Checkbox Control: Overwrite Return-path Address with Reply-to Address (Unchecked, with help icon).

2.  **Phishing Email Headers** (Section Header):
    *   Checkbox Control: Overwrite Fixed Return-path Address with Sender Address (Unchecked, with help icon).
    *   Checkbox Control (Partially visible): Disable Y X DUIGITEST Headers (Unchecked, with help icon).

All listed options utilize unselected checkboxes as the primary UI control and include a question mark icon for context-sensitive help/tooltips.
